statement.text: End-to-end anastomosis is the fundamental vascular surgical technique for joining two vessels or a graft to a vessel in a linear fashion. The technique involves spatulating the vessel ends for size match, placing precise intima-to-intima sutures, and creating a watertight, hemodynamically favorable connection. This anastomosis type is preferred for trauma repair, interposition grafts, and aortic procedures where the vessels are aligned on the same axis.
statement.formal: End-to-End Anastomosis: Spatulate ends (45° bevel or longitudinal cut) → Match diameters → Place corner sutures → Running polypropylene (5-0 to 7-0 depending on vessel size) → Continuous technique (or interrupted for small vessels) → Flush before completion → Test anastomosis

explanation.intuition: An end-to-end anastomosis is like splicing two pieces of hose together - you're connecting them in a straight line. To make sure the connection doesn't leak and blood flows smoothly, you need to bevel the ends (like cutting bread on an angle), match them up perfectly, and sew them with tiny stitches that only catch the outside layer of each vessel.
explanation.key_insight: The key to a perfect end-to-end anastomosis is tension-free approximation with precise intima-to-intima contact. If there's any tension on the suture line, it will leak or the suture will cut through. If the intima isn't kissing, a flap can form and cause thrombosis. Spatulating the ends (making them oblique) widens the anastomosis and prevents stenosis.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: (1) Prepare vessel ends by debriding any damaged tissue; (2) Spatulate the ends by cutting obliquely (45°) or making a longitudinal incision to widen; (3) Match vessel diameters - the smaller vessel can be spatulated more to match larger; (4) Flush with heparinized saline; (5) Place first suture at heel (posterior) with mattress-type bite; (6) Run anterior wall first (or posterior if you're inside the vessel); (7) Use 3-4mm bites, 3-4mm apart; (8) Keep sutures perpendicular to vessel edge; (9) Take full-thickness bites but don't catch back wall; (10) Before completing, flush and back-bleed to remove air/debris; (11) Complete anastomosis; (12) Test by releasing clamps - proximal first, then distal. Suture selection: Aorta 3-0/4-0, femoral 5-0/6-0, tibial 6-0/7-0 polypropylene.
common_misconceptions: You can sew through all layers and it will be fine - intima-to-intima contact is essential for healing
Bigger bites are stronger - smaller, precise bites prevent tearing and stenosis
You need interrupted sutures for all anastomoses - running technique is faster and usually equivalent
If it's leaking, just put more sutures - first try applying pressure, as sutures weaken the anastomosis

definitions_glossary.spatulation: Cutting vessel end obliquely or making longitudinal slit to widen anastomosis
definitions_glossary.intima_to_intima: Suture technique ensuring inner lining of vessels is in direct contact
definitions_glossary.heel: The posterior aspect of an anastomosis, sewn first in many techniques
definitions_glossary.toe: The anterior aspect of an anastomosis, completed last
definitions_glossary.back_bleeding: Allowing retrograde blood flow to flush debris before completing anastomosis

indications: Arterial trauma repair with primary anastomosis
contraindications: Tension on suture line (need interposition graft)
Need to preserve side branch at anastomosis site

vessel_preparation: Debride damaged or diseased vessel ends
Spatulate for size match and to widen

technique_options.interrupted: For very small vessels, pediatric, or when growth needed
technique_options.parachute: Place sutures first, then parachute vessel down - useful for deep anastomoses

steps: Place first suture at heel (posterior midpoint)
Run one arm around lateral wall to toe
Run other arm around medial wall to meet first
Alternatively, run anterior wall first from inside, then posterior

complications.management: Direct pressure first, additional sutures if needed, patch if major

complications.prevention: Spatulate ends, don't narrow the lumen with sutures

complications.management: Thrombectomy, may need revision of anastomosis

definition.@value: Surgical technique of joining two vessels or a graft to a vessel in a linear, end-to-end configuration

sources.citation: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery, 9th Edition. Anastomotic Techniques.

learning_objectives: Describe the principles of end-to-end vascular anastomosis
Perform an end-to-end anastomosis with proper technique
Select appropriate suture material for different vessel sizes
clinical_pearls: Spatulate the ends to prevent stenosis - the anastomosis should be wider than the vessel
If it's leaking, try pressure first - additional sutures create more needle holes
Always flush before completing - air and debris cause embolization and thrombosis
The parachute technique is your friend for deep or challenging anastomoses
Don't catch the back wall on your suture bites - it creates stenosis

medicalCode.description: Bypass aorta using autologous tissue substitute
